title: Instructional Design for Developing 21st-Century Social Competencies in Online STEM Education

context.prior_knowledge: Advanced-level expertise in the field, extensive practical experience, basic understanding of social issues, and digital tool proficiency
context.additional_context: Long-term program for pre-service/in-service teachers in digitally supported environments. Addresses post-COVID-19 online education shifts by strengthening social competencies. Focuses on cultivating educational design capabilities for community issue resolution

learning_goals: Learners Can Design Collaborative Learning Activities Comprising Three Stages (Planning-Execution-Feedback) Using Google Workspace or Microsoft Teams Tools in Online STEM Classroom Environments, Perform Real-Time Communication (Chat/Video) and Task-Based Collaboration (Document Sharing/Simultaneous Editing) with Over 80% Participation, and Contribute to Social Relationship Building and Digital Citizenship Development

Learners Can Propose Creative Solutions to Three or More Social Issues (e.g., Climate Change, Digital Divide, Public Health) Using Project-Based Assessment Tools (e.g., Problem-Solving Tasks, Design Thinking Workshops) and Write Reports Meeting the Evaluation Rubric’s Critical Thinking (≥3/5) and Creativity (≥3/5) Criteria

Learners Evaluate Problem-Solving, Self-Directed Learning, Data Analysis, and Modeling Competencies Over Six Months Through Blended (Synchronous/Asynchronous) Activities (2 Weekly Live Workshops + 3 Asynchronous Tasks/Week), Propose a Data-Driven Model for Solving Real-World Social Problems in a Final Project, and Achieve Peer/Instructor Evaluation Standards (5-Point Scale, ≥4) and Quantitative Performance Metrics (e.g., Model Accuracy ≥80%)
difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
